articles.headline: Binance Founder Pleads Guilty to Violating Money Laundering Rules
articles.snippet: Changpeng Zhao will pay a $50 million fine and step down as chief executive of the company he created, the latest blow to the crypto world since the implosion of FTX last year.
articles.abstract: Changpeng Zhao will pay a $50 million fine and step down as chief executive of the company he created, the latest blow to the crypto world since the implosion of FTX last year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Changpeng Zhao, the founder of Binance, the largest cryptocurrency exchange in the world, pleaded guilty to money laundering violations, the government said on Tuesday, a stunning blow to the most powerful and influential figure in the global crypto industry.
articles.byline: By David Yaffe-Bellany, Emily Flitter, Matthew Goldstein and Glenn Thrush

articles.headline: Before Altman’s Ouster, OpenAI’s Board Was Divided and Feuding
articles.snippet: Sam Altman confronted a member over a research paper that discussed the company, while directors disagreed for months about who should fill board vacancies.
articles.abstract: Sam Altman confronted a member over a research paper that discussed the company, while directors disagreed for months about who should fill board vacancies.
articles.lead_paragraph: Before Sam Altman was ousted from OpenAI last week, he and the company’s board of directors had been bickering for more than a year. The tension got worse as OpenAI became a mainstream name thanks to its popular ChatGPT chatbot.
articles.byline: By Cade Metz, Tripp Mickle and Mike Isaac

articles.headline: Israel and Hamas Agree to Cease-Fire in Exchange for Hostage Release
articles.snippet: The agreement calls for a pause in the fighting and for Hamas to free 50 of the captives it seized in its Oct. 7 raid on Israel. Hamas said Israel would release 150 Palestinians held in Israeli prisons.
articles.abstract: The agreement calls for a pause in the fighting and for Hamas to free 50 of the captives it seized in its Oct. 7 raid on Israel. Hamas said Israel would release 150 Palestinians held in Israeli prisons.
articles.lead_paragraph: After more than six weeks of war, the Israeli government and Hamas announced Wednesday morning that they would uphold a brief cease-fire in Gaza to allow for the release of 50 hostages Hamas captured during its assault last month on Israel.

articles.headline: The Strange $55 Million Saga of a Netflix Series You’ll Never See
articles.snippet: After suitors flocked to a sci-fi project by Carl Rinsch, director of a single movie, the winner handed over money and control. They’re still fighting.
articles.abstract: After suitors flocked to a sci-fi project by Carl Rinsch, director of a single movie, the winner handed over money and control. They’re still fighting.
articles.lead_paragraph: Near the height of the streaming boom in the fall of 2018, a half-dozen studios and video platforms lined up to woo a little-known filmmaker named Carl Erik Rinsch. He had directed only one movie, “47 Ronin.” It was a commercial and critical dud, and Mr. Rinsch’s tussles with its producers had raised eyebrows, even in an industry where such conflicts are the norm.

articles.headline: Why China and Boeing Still Need Each Other
articles.snippet: A thaw in relations between the U.S. and China may help the manufacturer sell more planes — and finally deliver aircraft ordered years ago.
articles.abstract: A thaw in relations between the U.S. and China may help the manufacturer sell more planes — and finally deliver aircraft ordered years ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: Boeing’s commercial aircraft sales to China have slowed to a trickle as U.S.-Chinese relations have soured. But there are new prospects for the company to regain traction.
articles.byline: By Niraj Chokshi and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: For Election Workers, Fentanyl-Laced Letters Signal a Challenging Year
articles.snippet: As overheated rhetoric and threats rise, people are leaving election jobs in record numbers.
articles.abstract: As overheated rhetoric and threats rise, people are leaving election jobs in record numbers.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the people who run elections at thousands of local offices nationwide, 2024 was never going to be an easy year. But the recent anonymous mailing of powder-filled envelopes to election offices in five states offers new hints of how hard it could be.

articles.headline: It’s the Most Wonderful Time of the Year (for the Economy)
articles.snippet: Three decades of monthly retail spending show how important the holiday season is to our economy.
articles.abstract: Three decades of monthly retail spending show how important the holiday season is to our economy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Three decades of monthly retail spending show how important the holiday season is to our economy.

articles.headline: Retailers Need You to Buy That Diamond Ring. No, Seriously.
articles.snippet: American consumers are the biggest spenders in the world. For the companies that rely on them, the last few weeks of the year are crucial to making a solid bulk of their revenues and driving profit.
articles.abstract: American consumers are the biggest spenders in the world. For the companies that rely on them, the last few weeks of the year are crucial to making a solid bulk of their revenues and driving profit.
articles.lead_paragraph: American consumers are the biggest spenders in the world. For the companies that rely on them, the last few weeks of the year are crucial to making a solid bulk of their revenues and driving profit.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Jordyn Holman

articles.headline: As Its Economy Sputters, Britain Cuts Taxes Ahead of Election
articles.snippet: The U.K.’s top financial official, Jeremy Hunt, outlined measures to spur business investment and push more people into jobs.
articles.abstract: The U.K.’s top financial official, Jeremy Hunt, outlined measures to spur business investment and push more people into jobs.
articles.lead_paragraph: With a general election at most 14 months away, the British government said on Wednesday that it will cut taxes for millions of workers starting early next year.
